comments.commentBody: Life involves not only a replication system but a metabolic system that supports replication and all other life functions.  So an artificial replicating system without an artificial metabolic system seems quite a distance yet from a truly living artificial system.
It had its UPS AND DOWNS. I love rebuses (rebbe) because when you get that 'aha' moment and figure it out, then it's just fun after that.

oh yay Viv on TOP UP.

Dallums, I once put TOP DOWN and got in the wind stream and my contact lens dried up in my eye :-( ,,, never wore contacts with the top down again.
Martin@55:  E plurebus unum?

Suejean – I never saw the remake of Miracle on 34th Street.  Now you've given me another reason not to watch it.  I have a friend who liked A Night to Remember and refused to see Titanic.  You know there are no remakes for Gone With The Wind or Casablanca or Citizen Kane and that's the way it should be.
Loved this HARD puzzle and needed Deb's comments to "get it"!  Very clever!

I loved the long answers in this puzzle. TOULOUSE LAUTREC indeed! No answer was really that hard - not even DUROC, which I have seen before - but it was still a challenging puzzle that took me 29 minutes to finish off (or finish UP?).

I am not sure what "bedclothes" has to do with "underwear". "Bedclothes" are bed linens, and "underwear" is not clothing designed to wear to bed...

I'm also curious about 62 across. Does it mean there is supposed to be an expression "to luck onto" something? If so, how is this expression used?

Loved this one, and not just because of 45A's clue. Brava Paula.

I was reminded of a story about 33A. He often had brushes (pun uninteded) with the gendarmes, but they were always deferential to him since they appreciated his artistic work. One time when they reluctantly had to take him in, as the policeman put on the hand cuffs he said to Lautrec, "Hope they're not too tight, Toulouse."

Hey Wags! You made the puzzle today! Now, let's see the rest of us...

I loved every one of the long entries. The shape of the grid allowed for 8 of them, not stacked. As xwd info explains, it has Super Symmetry. Cool. REF and UMP, ARM and LEG, a clever way to clue MOUNTER, well-clued short words, a new clue for OREO (thank you!) - a fun puzzle in every way. Thanks, Paula!

I loved how all those 15s were woven together. Quite the feat. I was able to complete it, though bARDS in CARDS spot had me on some goofy tangents.

I was nonplussed by the Underwear answer, but I think it did influence my thinking about "lick race". And by the I got to MOUNTER, I was really in the mood to reproduce, so I quickly xeroxed some old rabbit food bags. Playing air-cello for a bit helped as well.

A very stirring puzzle.
I thought there were all sorts of possibilities with this puzzle but Deb seems to have covered them all, except for MOUNTER.

Solving is such a personal experience and, as we see in blogs all the time, reactions to many of the most interesting can be wildly divergent. I enjoyed this puzzle as much as any I've done all year. Everything worked like it was supposed to for me. And whatever you think of the garments in question, "Tasteful bedclothes" is the clue of the year so far for me. It's clever and has the added twist of being completely unexpected in this venue.

As Groucho said, "I'm not in the habit of making threats, Sir, but there'll be a letter about this in the Times tomorrow morning!"

Like everyone else, I have spent some time pondering what 'life' is. And the only generalized notion I can come up with is its a physical pattern whose very nature resists entropy.

Since entropy itself is a constant of the universe, all life can do is move it out of its 'pattern' onto something else before decoherence takes over. Reproductive life takes the same principle, but with a pattern that raises total entropy in a system to make some small part of that system like itself. But that's all I got.

I'm 11 weeks pregnant right now (with my first), and I have found the past 6 weeks dealing with morning sickness unbelievably difficult - physically, but also mentally and emotionally. I suspect this is just the beginning. I don't have any mental health issues that I know of, but this pregnancy makes me want to cry out of frustration multiple times a day.

I can't imagine how much harder it would be if I had to go off drugs that kept me stable and sane. Frankly, based on what you wrote, I'd avoid pregnancy if I were you. Consider surrogacy or adoption. Pregnancy is really frikking hard.

The recent college graduates I work with can afford to buy cars but many of them are choosing not to. I followed their example last year and sold my car. We're still a minority, but as the population becomes increasingly urban, more and more people are choosing to go car-free.

I'm a 2 finger down scroller on my macpro and a thumb up scroller on my ipad. I never noticed they were different until I read this article and purposely checked.
I think my droid prepared me for the ipad and I am happy with all. Having them consistent absolutely makes sense but I was fortunate and adapted without realizing it.

This would be quite a change from the times I traveled to England in 1978 and 1980. Back in the day I traveled on my USAF identification card and a set of military orders. Likewise in 1992 going to and from Saudi Arabia for the Ceasefire Campaign of Operation Desert Storm. I dragged my duffel bags out to the USAF blue vehicle and heaved them in, got in with the other Airmen and away we went. We didn't need no stinking visas. HM's Customs were very polite, almost cursory. Perhaps this was because I traveled in uniform, the last 2 times in desert pattern Battle Dress Uniform and debarked on a US air base.
This service sounds like a better way to go to Blokelahoma, our pet name for Mother England. Cheers, mate.
Anyone who's quick might sneak a buss, but, for a rebuss, you need cooperation

Hi Richard,

You have a sharp eye. It's been fixed in the post and thanks!

Hey Deb, fix the typo in your penultimate paragraph!

Isn't REM an abbreviation, or is it an acronym or initialism?

Luck ONTO is not part of my vocabulary, like luck INTO would be (or "luck in to").

Perfect clue for 51A - Tipping

Fun puzzle - thanks!

Hi Richard,

You have a sharp eye. It's been fixed in the post and thanks!

This is another example of disgraceful politics on the part of the Republicans. Denying global warming, seeking to keep outrageous tax breaks, that even the rich don't want, going after environmental safeguards, and spending virtually all of their time trying to get Obama out of office in 2012 -- instead of acting like Senators --. If you don't get what is wrong here, you are part of the problem.
I thought the "tea party hobbits" were pro environment???  Or was that just that wack job from Fox?
This is beyond the pale. It's past time to line up the corporate loving Republicans and direct them to a prison to protect humanity from their dnagerously short-sighted and stupid greed.
I feel like Oliver Douglas in Green Acres.
